title: 103_hr107
content:
The Act is titled the "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993" and it applies to various sections. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies laws related to employment terms, health and safety, and employer-employee rights to Congress in the same way as they apply to private individuals and Executive agencies. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies various laws, such as the Social Security Act and the Civil Rights Act of 1964, to Congress in the same way as they apply to private individuals and Executive agencies. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies laws like the National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act, Civil Rights Act of 1964, Age Discrimination in Employment Act, Occupational Safety and Health Act, Title IX, Rehabilitation Act, Privacy Act, Age Discrimination Act, and Ethics in Government Act to Congress. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies various laws to Congress, including the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, Privacy Act of 1974, Age Discrimination Act of 1975, Ethics in Government Act of 1978, and Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. Congress and its instrumentalities are subject to the Freedom of Information Act to the same extent as Executive agencies. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies various laws to Congress, including the Freedom of Information Act. Chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code, relating to independent counsel, applies to Congress. This Act applies to Senators, Representatives, and Residents. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to Senators, Representatives, Residents, and certain employees of Congress. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to elected officers, Legislative Counsel, Capitol Police, and employees of Congress. Employees of various instrumentalities of Congress, including the Congressional Research Service, the General Accounting Office, and the Library of Congress, are subject to the laws outlined in the Congressional Accountability Act of 1993. District or State offices of Members are also included in this provision. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies to employees in the district or State office of a Member, treating them as affiliated branches of a private employer. Members can consider political affiliation and place of residence when hiring personal staff. Section 509 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is repealed. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 allows Members to consider political affiliation and place of residence when hiring personal staff. Section 509 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is repealed, and small business exemptions apply to Members based on their number of employees. The small business exemption applies to Members based on the number of employees, including those attributable to the Member, necessary to qualify as a small business. The number of employees attributable to a Member is calculated based on specific criteria outlined in the subsections. SEC. 3. PROMULGATION OF IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS.

Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, the House of Representatives and the Senate must create rules to implement the Act, including the laws in section 2, in accordance with Federal law. Failure to do so will result in being subject to Executive agency regulations.

SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL. If an individual is unhappy with an action taken under this Act, they can appeal in a Federal district court with the same rights as private persons under the referenced laws.
